Dialogue:
ES: Hello!  
CD: Hello!  
ES: What did you eat for lunch?  
CD: I ate pasta!  
ES: Pasta sounds good! Did you make it at home?  
CD: Yes, with tomato sauce.  
ES: Is the sauce homemade too?  
CD: I bought the sauce! Also, I added anchovies.  
ES: It's rare to have anchovies at home, isn't it?  
CD: I recently bought some! Do you like anchovies?  
ES: I don't remember eating it often. Is it fish?  
CD: Yes, it is. It's a paste made from sardines or something like that.  
ES: Is it sold in the pasta section?  
CD: Yes. I saw it there.  
ES: What does it taste like? It seems unique.  
CD: Well, it tastes like fish. Hahaha.  
ES: I'm curious. I'll check it out next time I'm at the supermarket!  
CD: Yes! What did you eat?  
ES: I had curry.  
CD: At home?  
ES: Yes, I quickly ate frozen rice with instant curry.  
CD: Retort curries from Muji are delicious, aren't they?  
ES: I like them too! What type do you prefer?  
CD: A safe choice would be butter chicken curry.  
ES: That's a classic! Are you okay with spicy food?  
CD: Yes, it's okay!  
ES: I also like spicy food, so I mostly buy green curry.  
CD: Is it quite spicy?  
ES: Yes, it is.  
CD: It might be a little too much for me. Haha.

ES: Hello.  
CD: Hello.  
ES: Do you usually listen to music?  
CD: Yes, I'm listening to music right now.  
ES: That's interesting! What kind of music do you like?  
CD: I was listening to the song "Just Look Up" by Ariana Grande.  
ES: Foreign music is quite appealing! But I haven't come across that song before.  
CD: Do you know the movie called "Look Up"?  
ES: Is it recent?  
CD: It's on Netflix, and that's the song from it.  
ES: I'll check out the song on YouTube later.  
CD: The movie is also recommended. Do you listen to Western music?  
ES: Yes, I enjoy Western music. I was a fan of Fifth Harmony during their prime.  
CD: Is that when there were five members?  
ES: Yes, exactly. After one member left, the group's momentum seemed to drop.  
CD: Camilla, right?  
ES: Yes. Are you well-versed in Western music?  
CD: I mainly listen to Western music. At karaoke, there are many songs I don't know.  
ES: I understand. Besides Ariana, who is your favorite singer?  
CD: I mostly listen to the classics like Taylor and Justin.  
ES: That's great. I used to listen to Justin's older songs a lot.  
CD: We might be around the same age.  
ES: I get that sense too. I love "Beauty and the Beat," the collaboration with Nicki Minaj.  
CD: That's awesome.  
ES: Even now, I can still get excited about it, but it is an older song, isn't it?  
CD: Yes. Justin looked really young in the music video.  
ES: It's been good discussing music.  
CD: Yes. That was when Justin had his bangs.  
ES: Those times were quite memorable.  
CD: Exactly. Thanks for the chat!

ES: Hello.  
AR: Hello, nice to meet you. How can I assist you today?  
ES: I'm feeling a bit nervous.  
AR: Do you get shy around strangers?  
ES: Yes, I get very nervous.  
AR: That's understandable.  
ES: By "the real thing," do you mean something like a presentation?  
AR: Yes, like a presentation. When I was younger, I wrote the character for 'people' (人) three times on my palm.  
ES: That brings back memories.  
AR: Many people did that.  
ES: I used to do it, too. Also, imagining the audience as potatoes helped.  
AR: That's a common technique.  
ES: Do children today still do things like 人人人?  
AR: My children are too young to understand that yet.  
ES: You have small children?  
AR: Yes, I have a 6-year-old and a 5-year-old. They enjoy playing nostalgic games.  
ES: Such games are enjoyable in any era. Do they play outside?  
AR: Yes, they prefer playing outside, especially since the coronavirus started.  
ES: A friend of mine said her son has too much energy, too.  
AR: There's a noticeable difference between boys and girls in how they play.  
ES: Indeed, there is a difference.  
AR: I've noticed girls tend to play more calmly.  
ES: Is your child also like that?  
AR: Girls can be more straightforward, but boys can be clingy and cute, too.  
ES: Being spoiled can be cute.  
AR: It brings out maternal instincts.  
ES: It's common for mothers and sons, fathers and daughters to get along well.  
AR: Children are pure, which is refreshing.  
ES: The purity of children is precious.  
AR: Absolutely. Goodbye!

ES: Hello.
EV: Hello, how can I assist you today?
ES: What did you have for lunch today?
EV: I had cold udon.
ES: Did you cool it after boiling?
EV: Yes, I did.
ES: That sounds perfect for a hot summer day. Did you have it with mentsuyu?
EV: Yes, I had it with mentsuyu.
ES: Recently, I've been experimenting with different udon flavors.
EV: There are many variations to explore.
ES: It keeps things interesting. What other flavors do you enjoy?
EV: I like it with egg and green onion.
ES: Simple combinations are often the best.
EV: I agree. Sometimes, I use soy sauce for a different taste.
ES: Soy sauce does add a nice flavor. I've been adding rice cakes to my udon lately.
EV: Like ozoni with mochi?
ES: Yes, sometimes with miso for added flavor.
EV: Miso is a great addition. It sounds delicious.
ES: It's also good with a bit of gochujang.
EV: That sounds appetizing. Do you find your appetite decreases in the summer?
ES: Yes, it does. Any food suggestions?
EV: You could try spicy foods; they might help.
ES: I do crave spicy foods in the summer. How well do you handle spicy foods?
EV: Medium spicy is fine for me.
ES: Same here. Very spicy foods can upset my stomach.
EV: Understood. Is there anything else you need?

ES: Hello!
EV: Hello, nice to meet you.
ES: What do you usually do during this time?
EV: Playing games or reading manga on holidays.
ES: What kind of games do you play?
EV: I often play hunting games and RPGs on PS4.
ES: Do you play smartphone games?
EV: I play a little. I play baseball and Dragon Ball games.
ES: There's a baseball game on smartphones? What's it called?
EV: It's called Prospi. If you don't like rigid games, PowerPro is better.
ES: Is it a game with actual athletes as characters?
EV: Yes, they often feature it in commercials.
ES: Do you like baseball?
EV: Yes, I watch it sometimes.
ES: Do you have a favorite team?
EV: I don't have any favorite. I like watching close games on my computer.
ES: Close games are exciting. I want to watch a Nippon-Ham Fighters game.
EV: My home is in Hokkaido, so it's a bit far. If it's a visitor, then maybe.
ES: Is there a stadium nearby where I can watch a game?
EV: Since you're in Tokyo, you can go to the Dome.
ES: Have you ever watched a game live at the Dome?
EV: Yes, about 10 years ago.
ES: Is it different from watching it on TV?
EV: Yes. The cheering squad makes it more exciting.
ES: The sound must be amazing.
EV: Yes, but I don't understand much about types of pitches.

ES: Nice to meet you, please take care of me.
EV: Nice to meet you. I am here to assist you.
ES: Have you been on any trips recently?
EV: I haven't been traveling due to the current situation.
ES: It's quite difficult to go, isn't it?
EV: Yes, my plans to visit my parents were canceled.
ES: Is it because COVID-19 is spreading again?
EV: Yes, my mother contracted COVID.
ES: Is your mother okay?
EV: Yes, her treatment is finished.
ES: I see. There are people around me who have lingering aftereffects.
EV: Understood. My mother works at a hospital, so exposure was likely.
ES: In this day and age, working at a hospital is admirable.
EV: Yes, cases have started to increase again.
ES: Didn't your family get disappointed when you canceled your trip home?
EV: No, we can't enter the house.
ES: I see, it would be nice if you could visit your hometown again.
EV: I hope to return in the winter.
ES: Do you remember what the infection situation was like last winter?
EV: It was prevalent. I monitored my health at the hotel.
ES: There are a lot of things to be considerate about, aren't there?
EV: Yes, it had calmed down around spring, but has increased again.
ES: The situation remains one where we cannot let our guard down recently.
EV: Understood. Travel risk increases with excitement.
ES: After all, when you go back to your hometown or travel, you want to go out, don't you?
EV: Correct. Paying money implies wanting to enjoy the experience.
ES: I understand the feeling of wanting to have fun if you're going to do it anyway.
EV: We need to endure it for a while. Let's take care of our health.
ES: Let's take care of our health!
EV: Yes, thank you.

ES: Hello!
DN: Hello.
ES: Any plans for dinner?
DN: Not yet. How about you?
ES: Still deciding. Bought some pork yesterday.
DN: Pork belly?
ES: Thinly sliced peach meat.
DN: Difficult to plan?
ES: Yes, it's challenging. How do you decide?
DN: I buy things at evening sales and eat them as they are.
ES: Is evening cheaper than morning?
DN: Yes, especially fish and sashimi.
ES: Nice! Do you cook it right away?
DN: More like arranging than cooking.
ES: Like grilling meat?
DN: Yes, with sauce and vegetables.
ES: Convenient. Is the sauce in the seasoning section?
DN: In retort pouches in the curry and Chinese food section.
ES: I'll check it out next time.
DN: Also, use pasta sauce to cook meat with vegetables.
ES: Pasta sauce works too! What flavor?
DN: Tomato sauce with chicken or minced meat and vegetables.
ES: Minced meat cooks quickly!
DN: Yes, and dilute clam vongole sauce with water, add potatoes for soup.
ES: Sounds like a good soup!
DN: Yes, add white fish, clams, mushrooms.
ES: Use white fish as is?
DN: Usually processed, use as is.
ES: Helpful for fish recipes!
DN: Pasta sauce is very convenient!

ES: Hello. Nice to meet you.  
DN: Hello. Nice to meet you.  
ES: Have you been on a trip recently?  
DN: No, I went outside the prefecture, but I didn't go on a trip.  
ES: It's difficult to go out these days, isn't it?  
DN: Yes, but I sometimes take the express bus to visit my son in Kansai on weekends.  
ES: So, you're in Kansai! Are you from the Kanto region?  
DN: No, I travel from Aichi Prefecture to Osaka and Kobe.  
ES: Understood. I'm in Tokyo now, but I'd like to visit Aichi and Osaka too.  
DN: My other son is in Kanagawa, so I take the bus there too sometimes.  
ES: You must be quite experienced with bus travel. Do you enjoy it?  
DN: The Shinkansen is expensive, but the bus is more affordable.  
ES: The bus is significantly cheaper than the Shinkansen, isn't it?  
DN: Yes, there are high-speed buses with capsule seats between Aichi, Osaka, and Tokyo.  
ES: Are the capsule seats completely private?  
DN: The capsule is designed so you can stretch your legs.  
ES: That sounds fascinating. Privacy must be well-maintained.  
DN: Yes, I always choose a three-row seat when traveling between Aichi and Tokyo, but the capsule is the best.  
ES: Are all three rows capsules?  
DN: Yes, this bus has 17 seats, and all of them are capsules.  
ES: There are few seats. Is there a restroom on the bus?  
DN: No, these buses don't have restrooms.  
ES: That's a bit concerning. Are there bathroom breaks?  
DN: Yes, there are 3 breaks, including one before midnight and another around 5 AM.  
ES: That should be manageable. It seems like you can enjoy the ride comfortably.  
DN: Yes, and recently, I played a public piano at the Hamamatsu SA during a break.  
ES: They feature the town piano program on NHK, right?  
DN: Yes, it's been popular.  
ES: Have you appeared on it?  
DN: No, I just play for fun and leave.
